parties.title: Rajesh Kumar v. State of Maharashtra

tldr60: Supreme Court held that anticipatory bail can't be denied just because the offense is serious. Court ruled this because Article 21 protects personal liberty unless exceptional circumstances exist. This means accused persons have better protection from arrest, but prosecution must show compelling reasons to deny pre-arrest bail.

brief5min.facts: Rajesh Kumar applied for anticipatory bail in a corruption case. The High Court denied it saying the offense was serious. Kumar appealed to the Supreme Court arguing his fundamental rights were violated.
brief5min.issues:
• Can anticipatory bail be denied solely because the offense is serious?
• What factors should courts consider when granting pre-arrest bail?
brief5min.holding: Anticipatory bail cannot be denied merely on the ground that the offense is serious.
brief5min.reasoning: The Court emphasized that personal liberty is a fundamental right under Article 21. Denial of anticipatory bail should be based on specific circumstances like tampering with evidence or influencing witnesses, not just the seriousness of the charge.
brief5min.disposition: Appeal allowed. High Court directed to reconsider the anticipatory bail application on merits.

keyQuotes.quote: Personal liberty is too precious to be denied on vague and general allegations.
Seriousness of the offense alone cannot be the sole criteria for denying anticipatory bail.

parties.title: Tech Solutions Pvt Ltd v. Commissioner of Income Tax

tldr60: Delhi High Court ruled that software development qualifies for tax deductions under IT Act because coding is manufacturing in the digital age. This means tech companies can claim significant tax benefits, reducing their effective tax rate and encouraging more investment in software development in India.

brief5min.facts: Tech Solutions claimed deduction under Section 80-IB for software development. Income Tax Department denied it saying software isn't manufacturing. Company challenged this in High Court.
brief5min.issues:
• Does software development qualify as 'manufacturing' under the Income Tax Act?
• Can digital products be treated same as physical goods for tax purposes?
brief5min.holding: Software development constitutes manufacturing and qualifies for deduction under Section 80-IB.
brief5min.reasoning: The Court noted that in the digital economy, creating software involves transforming raw inputs (code, algorithms) into finished products (applications). This process is analogous to traditional manufacturing and deserves similar tax treatment.
brief5min.disposition: Petition allowed. Tax department directed to grant deduction and refund excess tax collected.

keyQuotes.quote: In the digital age, manufacturing extends beyond physical goods to include software creation.
Tax laws must evolve to recognize the realities of the modern economy.

parties.title: Priya Sharma v. Reliance Industries Ltd

tldr60: Bombay High Court held that companies must investigate harassment complaints within 90 days because delayed justice enables workplace misconduct. This means stricter timelines for corporate investigations and faster relief for harassment victims, potentially leading to more accountability in Indian workplaces.

brief5min.facts: Priya Sharma filed harassment complaint against her supervisor at Reliance. Company's Internal Committee took 8 months to investigate. Sharma approached High Court seeking mandamus for timely investigation.
brief5min.issues:
• What is reasonable time limit for investigating workplace harassment?
• Can courts intervene in internal company investigation processes?
brief5min.holding: Companies must complete harassment investigations within 90 days of complaint filing.
brief5min.reasoning: The Court emphasized that delayed investigations traumatize victims and allow perpetrators to continue misconduct. Swift justice is essential for maintaining safe workplaces and protecting women's fundamental rights.
brief5min.disposition: Mandamus issued directing company to complete investigation within 30 days and implement findings immediately.

keyQuotes.quote: Justice delayed in harassment cases is justice denied to victims who continue to suffer.
Corporate accountability requires swift and decisive action against workplace misconduct.
